issue.title: Server stops accepting connections after a while

repository.name: rustless
repository.description: REST-like API micro-framework for Rust. Works with Iron.

issue.body: I have very little information regarding the issue yet, and this could be an Iron issue. The issue is basically that after some indeterminate amount of time (typically a few hours to a few days) the server seems to stop accepting new connections. It doesn't panic or return any errors anywhere, as far as I can tell. Any requests I attempt to make to it will time out.

body: I think that Hyper must have something like [KeepAliveTimeout](http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/core.html#keepalivetimeout) in Apache.

@andor44 I think that you may try to use nginx as a reverse proxy in front of Rustless/Huper to work-around the issue. Nginx could handle a big amount of connections without any issues and it has usable keep-alive settings. I think nginx is required for blocking servers anyway.

@s-panferov I'll give that a shot.

[Here's](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/blob/79200ed49646331700853521ec688c9de5515197/src/server/mod.rs#L129-146) the relevant part of the code. I'm not sure how deep down the rabbit hole this should be handled though. Probably as deep as [this](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/blob/master/src/http.rs#L368) though I'm not sure how easily you can specify a timeout in the current Hyper architecture.

issue.title: Static file MIME type inferred incorrectly for 404s

repository.name: nickel.rs
repository.description: An expressjs inspired web framework for Rust

issue.body:
As I alluded to before without explaining properly, what I mean is it looks like the mime type is inferred from the file extension, but this should be overridden on certain events. 

If you load up nickel-bootstrap and put in /images/afilethatdoesntexist.jpg instead of getting a 404 I get a firefox (YMMV) "image cannot be displayed because it contains errors" response. 

Above is all speculation so far - it could be something else entirely. It could also be a hyper issue, depending on where the handover is. 

Interestingly this doesn't occur in chrome, which displays the correct "file not found" response.

issue.title: error reading status line

repository.name: nickel.rs
repository.description: An expressjs inspired web framework for Rust

issue.body:
Seeing this when accessing a nickel app via apache's mod_proxy:

```
The timeout specified has expired: proxy: error reading status line from remote server localhost:8080
```

Might be a new thing (i.e.: after the hyper port). Has anyone else seen this? Looking with GDB, I see the worker thread hanged on CloneTcpStream#read().

body: The current IO doesn't provide a way to specify a timeout, which makes this harder.
@andor44 have you tried to use a reverse proxy already? Has it helped?
Yes. I am using nginx, and it uses HTTP 1.0 for reverse proxying requests, which doesn't have keep-alive as part of the spec, and it works perfectly.

issue.title: Specify timeout for client requests?
issue.body:
A few times while integration testing a library I'm building with Hyper, the test runner has hung infinitely due to what I assume is an HTTP request that's never timing out. Is it possible to specify a timeout for a request? Should the default be infinite, as it seems to be?

IIRC there isn't an implementation of network timeouts in std, which might explain the current behavior. Any tips on debugging a request that hangs to figure out what it's doing?

issue.title: Stalled requests due to delayed hyper server replies

body: When will this bug be fixed? timeout should be an urgent feature.

Timeouts won't be supported by TcpStreams until Rust 1.1, which would be
mid June. To support timeouts in hyper earlier, we'd need to explore using
an additional thread, but it's performance may suffer too much.

In the mean time, I suggest putting nginx in front of your server, which
handles this well.

On Sat, Apr 18, 2015, 10:24 AM Young Woo notifications@github.com wrote:

> When will this bug be fixed? timeout should be an urgent feature.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/issues/368#issuecomment-94184696.

All right, thanks. But what about the client? Are there any good ways to
add timeout to a HttpClient

On 2015419 2:15 Sean McArthur notifications@github.com wrote:

> Timeouts won't be supported by TcpStreams until Rust 1.1, which would be
> mid June. To support timeouts in hyper earlier, we'd need to explore using
> an additional thread, but it's performance may suffer too much.
> 
> In the mean time, I suggest putting nginx in front of your server, which
> handles this well.
> 
> On Sat, Apr 18, 2015, 10:24 AM Young Woo notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> > When will this bug be fixed? timeout should be an urgent feature.
> > 
> > 
> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> > https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/issues/368#issuecomment-94184696.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/issues/368#issuecomment-94188584.

issue.title: Does Iron handle many connections correctly? (wrk2 benchmarking)

repository.name: iron
repository.description: An Extensible, Concurrent Web Framework for Rust

issue.body:
Hi,

(cc @nanoant, as he might be interested in this as well)

I'm running the following example as part of a benchmark:

```
extern crate iron;

use iron::prelude::*;
use iron::status;

fn main() {
    Iron::new(|_: &mut Request| {
        Ok(Response::with((status::Ok, "CHAPTER I. Down the Rabbit-Hole  Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, <and what is the use of a book,> thought Alice <without pictures or conversations?> So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her. There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, <Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!> (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge. In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again. The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well. Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards......")))
    }).http("172.16.0.1:8080").unwrap();
}
```

On the following version of rust:

```
[jlouis@daemonette rust]$ rustc -vV
rustc 1.0.0-nightly (a52182ffd 2015-04-17) (built 2015-04-17)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: a52182ffdedaabb3b72a11e8a67a411124ecb9ac
commit-date: 2015-04-17
build-date: 2015-04-17
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.0.0-nightly
```

The `Cargo.lock` file is down at the bottom of this, which I hope is enough for reproduction.

Running wrk on the data obtains a good result (10k connections, 15 seconds, as fast as possible):

```
[jlouis@lady-of-pain WebFrameworkBenchmark]$ wrk -t8 -c10000 -d15s http://172.16.0.1:8080/                 Running 15s test @ http://172.16.0.1:8080/
  8 threads and 10000 connections
  Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max   +/- Stdev
    Latency   354.72us  535.78us 201.53ms   99.73%
    Req/Sec    44.90k     3.23k   46.94k    96.00%
  669907 requests in 15.03s, 1.35GB read
  Socket errors: connect 0, read 9485, write 764, timeout 0
Requests/sec:  44580.66
Transfer/sec:     91.71MB
```

But if I take Gil Tene's wrk2 (https://github.com/giltene/wrk2), and ask for a request rate of 30000 req/s on 10000 connections, then Iron fails to obtain any sizeable number of connections:

```
[jlouis@lady-of-pain WebFrameworkBenchmark]$ wrk2 -t8 -c10000 -d60s -R 30000 http://172.16.0.1:8080/       
Running 1m test @ http://172.16.0.1:8080/
  8 threads and 10000 connections
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 1.246ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 1.265ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 1.235ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 1.179ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 9223372036854776.000ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 9223372036854776.000ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 9223372036854776.000ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread calibration: mean lat.: 1.104ms, rate sampling interval: 10ms
  Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max   +/- Stdev
    Latency     1.20ms  408.35us   2.48ms   68.42%
    Req/Sec     6.25     32.88   333.00     96.08%
  2885 requests in 1.00m, 5.93MB read
  Socket errors: connect 0, read 84, write 75042, timeout 190018
Requests/sec:     47.88
Transfer/sec:    100.85KB
```

In fact, it produces many many connection timeouts. Testing the same workload with the following webservers work as expected (do mind kernel tuning), on a setup with two physical machines sharing a 1 gigabit wired connection, which has been load tested beforehand:
- Go 1.4.2 net/http package
- JVM 8u40 undertow.io
- Erlang 17.5.1, cowboy 1.x
- Node.js v0.12.2 running in a cluster.js configuration

I _think_ the problem is coordinated omission in `wrk` together with Iron's inability to handle sudden capacity spikes. For the overview, see Gil Tene's React 2014 talk here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9MKY4KypBzg

Coordinated omission starts at 42:57, but the whole thing is worth watching. The problem is that `wrk` "synchronizes" to Iron and doesn't issue new requests while the first ones are completing. In turn, this means that you only see a single request which is "in flight", and you are not measuring that other requests can't complete were they issued in the meantime. Tene's `wrk2` issues new requests at a steady rate, so it doesn't wait until the first request is completing before trying to issue the next one. Clearly something is amiss here, since Iron acts in a way that is completely different from other known web frameworks. But I only have a hypothesis at best. 

I find the test interesting and easily reproducible. As it stands, I'm interested in what can be done to tune Rust so it doesn't "fail" the test. My guess is I may need to tune the number of sockets which accept new connections, or bump the thread count upwards. The kernel is configured with a net.core.somaxconn setting of 64k so there should be ample buffering available in the kernel for new connections, so this can't be it. Also, wrk2 only measures after 10 seconds, so there is a warmup period before the system starts actual measurements.

Other systems required some hand-tuning in order not to hit an artificial bottleneck, so I'm interested in what you would tune in Rust/Iron to achieve parity with the other frameworks.

Finally, the `Cargo.lock` file:

```
[root]
name = "helloworld"
version = "0.0.1"
dependencies = [
 "iron 0.1.16 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]

[[package]]

]

[[package]]
```

issue.title: server hanging after running for over 30 seconds

repository.name: nickel.rs
repository.description: An expressjs inspired web framework for Rust

issue.body:
I've a Debian server and I'm trying to run the release version of my [simple web application](https://github.com/freiguy1/schedule-gen-web) using nickel.rs, and after it's been running for as little as 30 seconds, it stops responding.  I added a middleware to log every request, and that doesn't even get reached.  When I use `curl` on the server pointed to localhost, that acts the same way as the browsers.  They just spin indefinitely.

The worst problem is that I try the same code/same version of rust on a different Ubuntu server and it never hangs.

Any idea how to remedy this problem?
